comments.body: Quite a major change... and apparently only introduced in the recent beta (earlier EAPs of 202.1 didn't get stuck on this dialog) lol

As I'm not familiar with Scala I will ask why do we have to write singe case here? 
Does it allow us for some type interference or is it not to catch Throwable?
Is it some kind of Scala convention to prefer single case over if?
It's just that I checked the impl of `super.teardown`, and they simply always throw a `new Exception` in case of any IDE errors (yeah lol xD)

> Is it some kind of Scala convention to prefer single case over if?

I'd say that yes, Scala likes pattern matching in general (even in cases where `if-else` could be equivalently used), and even requires pattern matching in certain cases — most notably for `catch` clause, even when just catching a single exception type
It doesn't look great but just as you pointed out, this is duct tape we are planning to remove when appropriate issue is closed?

This would've stalled with the old implementation since the dialog wasn't showing up at all.
It'd also fail on `acceptBranchDeletionOnSlideOut` — I only added `rejectBranchDeletionOnSlideOut` for the sake of _crop rotation_ aka _pÅ‚odozmian_ ðŸŒ¾

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +98,102 @@    intelliJ.machete.checkoutBranch("develop")
    intelliJ.machete.slideOutBranch("call-ws")
    intelliJ.machete.rejectBranchDeletionOnSlideOut()
    branchAndCommitRowsCount = intelliJ.machete.refreshModelAndGetRowCount()
    // 4 branch rows (`call-ws` is also no longer there) + 3 commit rows

comments.body: While you're here... pls add a mention to development-guide.md that installing Scala plugin might be useful for editing UI tests
